data.value: This conjugate gradient algorithm is based on that of Polak and Ribiere .
Conjugate gradient methods tend to work better when:
has a unique global minimizing point, and no local minima or    other stationary points,
is, at least locally, reasonably well approximated by a    quadratic function of the variables,
is continuous and has a continuous gradient,
is not too large, e.g., has a norm less than 1000,
Objective function to be minimized. Here
must be a 1-D array of the variables that are to be changed in the search for a minimum, and
. It must be a 1-D array of values.
A function that returns the gradient of
. The returned value must be a 1-D array. Defaults to None, in which case the gradient is approximated numerically (see
. Must be supplied whenever additional fixed parameters are needed to completely specify the functions
Stop when the norm of the gradient is less than

is approximated numerically. Can be a scalar or a 1-D array. Defaults to
, with eps the floating point machine precision.  Usually

Minimize a function using a nonlinear conjugate gradient algorithm.
Example 1: seek the minimum value of the expression

value: a*u**2 + b*u*v + c*v**2 + d*u + e*v + f
